description: From Middle English methaphesik, methaphisik, methaphisique, metaphesyk, methafisik, metaphesyk, methephysyk, from Old French metafisique, methaphisique and Medieval Latin metaphysica, methephisica; equivalent to meta- +â€Ž physic.

entries.meaning: (philosophy, uncountable, archaic) The field of study of metaphysics.
examples: With reference to general Philosophy or Metaphysic proper, psychology may be viewed as a kind of common ground whereon thinkers of widely different schools may meet.

entries.meaning: (philosophy, countable) The metaphysical system of a particular philosopher or of a particular school of thought.
examples: The uncertain conclusions of an ill-conducted analogy, and a false metaphysic, were mixed with a few simple precepts derived from observation, which probably made the whole of the science of prognostication in its earliest and purest state.

entries.meaning: (philosophy, countable) A fundamental principle or key concept.
examples: What we need as a metaphysic and what the logical realists are at least glimpsing, is the principle of contradiction.
